11:05 am
PM

With the ECB buying corporates today and following on from the observation that some of LVMH’s bonds are trading on negative yields, we did a quick screen for European non-financials with any debt tranches on negative yields. Quite a few Swiss names appear (or companies with some CHF-denominated debt), unsurprising given Swiss govt yields are now below zero out to 20 years! Every Swiss QCC name which has any debt has at least one tranche on negative yields. And on equity FCF yields between 3.6%-5.7% look very cheap comparing across their own capital structures. We are buyers of all of the following:

PM

QCC stands for quality cash converters, i think

PM

A Northern filter

BE

11:12 am
BE

Canaccord worries about tax.

BE

Which throw sand into the divi, apparently.

BE

Here's the upshot.

11:12 am
BE

We see the gradually changing Chilean tax regime through 2018 pressuring the ANTO
net margin and dividend. The company has a stated payout ratio of 35% now, but on our
forecasts of a lower net margin going forward we think only a ~2% dividend yield is likely
through 2018. We do not see the potential for ANTO to return to a +3% dividend yield
until after 2018.

BE

After having adjusted for the higher tax expected at ANTO through 2018 and beyond,
our revised target price on the stock is 475p/share. With less than 10% potential
upside to our target and an estimated 1-2% dividend yield in 2016, we downgrade our
rating on ANTO to HOLD.
We think that better than expected cost progression at Zaldivar and lower taxes could
both provide a potential upside catalyst for the stock at the half year stage.
Alternatively, an exceedingly high tax rate in 2016 could prevent the company from
hitting our dividend forecast for the year. We also see the potential for lower than
forecast debt reduction going into 2017 should copper prices remain subdued for H2
2016.

PM

Suppose the company is pretty much stuck in Chile, paying 35%

11:15 am
BE

And still trading at a gigantic premium because of its perception as a cashflow-positive miner with a bulletproof balance sheet.

BE

One could argue it's neither of these things any more.

BE

(Trailing PE of 1050, incidentally.)

11:15 am
PM

(wot?)

BE

(31 forward.)

PM

(ok)

11:16 am
BE

Back to Canaccord.

BE

New CEO may signal shift in financial focus
Ivan Arriagada was appointed the new CEO of Antofagasta on 8 April this year. While
the commentary on the transition was based much around how the strategy remains
unchanged at Antofagasta, we also think that the financial fortunes of the company
over the tenure of the incoming CEO could be significantly different than they were
under the past CEO. Under the helm of Diego Hernandez for the past 4 years we have
watched ANTO move from US$1.5bn in net cash to US$1bn in net debt, as the
company has undergone necessary capex plans needed in order to reposition its
portfolio of copper assets. Looking forward, we do not think ANTO intends to further
build its net debt position and could even modestly decrease its debt position over the
coming 3 years.
Tail end of most growth projects in sight
Two of ANTO’s bigger projects are currently in commissioning mode with the Centinella
concentrate plant ramping up to 105ktpd and Antucoya ramping up production.
Encuentro Oxides has been slightly delayed to a 2017 completion date, with capex for
that project expected to fall off within a 12 month timeframe. Meanwhile Zaldivar
should be focused on further cost reduction with Los Pelambres looking to achieve
cost containment in the coming 24 months. Beyond existing operations and ongoing
projects, both the Los Pelambres debottlenecking and the Centinella second
concentrator project should be at least 4-5 years out.
Cost focus should step up in the coming year
Now that the asset portfolio has been repositioned, we think it is an ideal time to be
focusing on costs. Management has targeted another US$160mn in cost savings for
2016. Centinella unit costs need to decrease to the US$1.35/lb level, Antucoya is
aiming for a US$1.65/lb C1 unit cost. Los Pelambres is trying to maintain US$1.40/lb
and Zaldivar improve upon its targeted US$1.80/lb cost basis (which it is already
beating). ANTO could be well positioned to benefit in 2017 from both volume growth
and lower unit and capital costs

11:26 am
BE

Here's Deutsche.

BE

Essentra has today published a trading update. The company is guiding to a
13-18% reduction to Company consensus EBITA 2016E expectations. The
guided range of adjusted operating profit is now between £155m and £165m,
which compares to Company consensus of £190m (Reuters £192m). EBITA
guidance is for a broadly flat H2 (H2 2015 at £90m). Guidance incorporates a
better H2 than H1, with some of the cut due to timing and we do believe that
some of the downgrade would likely be one-off in nature.

BE

The mean reasons for the weaker outlook are:

Filters: Chinese destocking trends worsening since H2 2015, Indian
regulatory issues having a greater impact and delayed commercialisation
of projects with one particular project for a large multinational being taken
off the table (£9-10m of revenues). Some contract deferrals are potentially
going to come back on the table.

HPC integration slower than expected, leading to operational issues both
in the UK and US, mainly due to two sites where integration is being
delayed by about 6 months with 200 headcount leaving the organisation
later than expected.

11:26 am
BE

CEO Colin Day said on the call that the internal budgeting processes have not
been completed and in the meantime a conservative estimate has been made.
In addition, he announced that the company will be implementing cost cuts to
the middle management layer worth around £5m, which are not included in
guidance. As such, there is a possibility that the scope of the downgrade
moderates.
What we believe is the most negative point to come from today’s
announcement, however, is the HPC integration delay news. It looks likely that
the share price today will be down by the degree of earnings downgrade and
some de-rating on top. Coming into today Essentra was trading on 15x 2017E
P/E, 12x EV/EBITA and 3% dividend yield. With the profit downgrade coming
from the two parts of the business we expected to be the most defensive –
Filters and HPC – we believe that some derating is likely to take place.

BE

23.11p divi, in case you're doing the maths on the new yield.

BE

Outlook. Today's update comes as a disappointment, as previously we
would have assumed that our estimates were conservatively positioned,
owing to factors like the closure of Jarrow in Filters. We continue to
believe that the Health and Personal Care Packaging business should be
able to deliver mid-single-digit LFL growth over the medium term, but
today’s update does not inspire confidence in execution. Overall,
significant weakness may present an interesting buying opportunity, but
we see scope for some near-term caution.

11:33 am
BE

Who can summarise here? Jefferies, maybe.

BE

FY16 print from AUTO this morning, modestly ahead numbers, revenue
£281.6m, +10.0% YoY, and adjusted EBITDA £181.9m, a 64.6% margin. FY16
dividend closed at 1.5p, and a rolling programme of share buybacks to start
immediately as leverage falls to 2.2x. Trevor Mather, CEO, 'the new financial
year has started well'. This constitutes another very sound print from AUTO.
Buy, PT 520p.

BE

Peer valuation klaxon!

11:34 am
BE

Just like 1999.

BE

How do we look at AUTO? Listed March 2015 at 235p. Another many/many network
online model, c.£4bn market cap puts it up there with JE and RMV in terms of scale...
AUTO, 14/17 EBITDA CAGR +13.2%, EPS CAGR +74.7%, trades on 20.1x CY17 EBITDA, 24.4x EPS, a 0.3x PEG;
JE, 14/17 EBITDA CAGR +66.2%, EPS CAGR +57.1%, 19.2x CY17 EBITDA, 29.4x EPS, a 0.5x PEG;
RMV, 14/17 EBITDA CAGR +13.0%, EPS CAGR +15.8%, 22.3x CY17 EBITDA, 27.4x EPS, a 1.7x PEG; and
ZPLA, 14/17 EBITDA CAGR +27.6%, EPS CAGR +27.4%, 16.4x CY17 EBITDA, 21.9x EPS, a 0.8x PEG.

BE

The context. Whenever are these prints not key? But, for AUTO, another important print
as the business pushes on from the IPO. FY16 consensus expectations currently stand at
revenue £280.3m, +9.5% YoY, and adjusted EBITDA £179.9m, a 64.2% margin.
FY17/FY18 expectations. FY17 consensus expectations, revenue £305.2m, +8.9% YoY,
adjusted EBITDA of £200.1m, a 65.6% margin. Looking further ahead, FY18 revenue
£334.0m, +9.4% growth, and adjusted EBITDA £224.3m, a margin of 67.2%.
The Hitwise context. Still understanding how relevant Hitwise is to the Autotrader model;
visits growth over FY16, +12.8%.
New car registrations data. In theory a useful data point for Autotrader, recent SMMT
data remains positive with record cumulative levels of new car registrations, though growth
rates easing from 2015. Mean monthly growth in 2016, +4.2% versus +6.8% at this point
during 2015.
Key takeaways from today's FY16 print:
1. Revenue £281.6m, +10.0% YoY, balanced contribution from volume and price,
ARPR +10.5% YoY to £1,384;
2. Adjusted EBITDA £181.9m, a 64.6% margin, quietly impressive;
3. FY17 guide, 'the new financial year has started well. Based upon having the
largest consumer audience, healthy relationships with our retailers, a robust
car buying market and a modest cost base decrease, the Board is confident
of further growth in the coming year';
4. Balance sheet, leverage drops to 2.2x from year-end FY14's 7.2x, the 2.0x objective
within line of sight. FY16 dividend 1.5p and a share repurchase programme
announced.
Analyst presentation. This morning, 0930 at the LSE.
In conclusion. Solid, quietly impressive print from AUTO, bodes well for FY17.

11:35 am
BE

That's David Reynolds, of course.

BE

And Caz, again, to chew through the buyback stuff.

BE

FY 17 guidance introduced, and rolling buyback program introduced: The
company has stated that the new financial year has started well. Based upon
having the largest consumer audience, healthy relationships with retailers, a
robust car buying market and an expected modest cost base decrease, the Board
is confident of further growth in the coming year. Auto Trader expects ARPR to
grow at high-single-digit rate in FY17 (JPMe +9.5%, company consensus
+8.7%) which we think could prove conservative, and the number of retailer
forecourts to remain stable (company consensus +0.7%, JPMe +0.5%). The
company also expects consumer services revenue to continue to grow
moderately and display advertising revenue to continue to grow at recent levels.
Company also highlighted that with the implementation of additional PSP
schemes in the future, combined with implementation of the SAYE scheme only
part way through FY 16, the charge for share-based payments was likely to at
least double in FY 17. We believe the guidance suggests an upgrade to FY 17
company consensus, which had included a £3m step-up in the cost base (JPMe
flat cost base).

Kaz Minerals PLC (KAZ:LSE): Last: 159.00, up 4 (+2.58%), High: 164.90, Low: 158.00, Volume: 994.08k
11:39 am
BE

Says they can double from here.

BE

Though as we've seen quite a lot, highly geared Kazakhstan copper miners can double, but also halve.

BE

It's complicated stuff, so I'm just going to grey it.

11:41 am
BE

Volume growth drives value transfer from debt to equity We upgrade KAZ Minerals from Underperform to Buy, increasing our PO to GBp 300. We

see execution risks falling after the Bozshakol project launch in February 2016. We shift
our target valuation year to 2018, when both the Bozshakol and Aktogay projects should
be ramped up, driving rapid deleveraging and thus unlocking equity value. 2018E FCF
yield jumps to 16%. Potential near-term catalysts are: successful ramp-up of Bozshakol
(boosting confidence in execution), renegotiation of debt covenants, and launch of
Aktogay in 2017E.

BE

New PO set at 5x 2018E EBITDA, when key projects ramp up In 2018 KAZ approaches its medium term “steady-state”. By then, copper production
should more than triple vs. 2015 to c.300ktpa copper, as Bozhakol and Aktogay deliver
100kt and 105kt copper, respectively. EBITDA increases c. 5x to $1.1bn by 2018E,
ND/EBITDA drops from 11x to 2.9x. Our target EV/EBITDA multiple represents a c.30%
discount to peer average of 7x, reflecting our 2018 target year, as well as potential
country and execution risk.

BE

Bozhakol launch in February 2016 reduced execution risks The next growth project for KAZ is Aktogay. Construction is under way, commissioning
planned for 2017. We see Aktogay as lower risk as the design is similar to Bozshakol and
it is being built by the same contractor. Bozshakol should be a low-cost asset (first
quartile) with C1 cost 70 USc/lb on average for the first 10 years, thanks to by-product
credits from gold (120koz pa). Aktogay’s net cash costs are modelled at 107 USc/lb.

11:42 am
BE

Financing risks look manageable (thanks to China) The company is liquid near term with $1.3bn cash at end-2015 vs $682mn capex and
$312mn repayments. We expect that the PXF/CAT’s ND/EBITDA covenant, tested for H2
2016, will be waived. In 2017 we expect KAZ to be able to postpone short term liquidity
requirements. By then, we think execution risks will be lower (Aktogay is slated to launch
that year) and operating cashflow generation should be stronger thanks to Bozshakol
ramping up. More generally, we see copper growth story of KAZ as sponsored by China on
several dimensions (providing debt and technical expertise for construction, guaranteeing
off-take for the product), and see the risk of this sponsorship being pulled as very low.

BE

Though if you want a counter opinion, I have one of those too.

BE

Canaccord -- whose clout in the market is a wee bit less than Merrill -- chose a bad day to start Kaz with a "sell".

11:43 am
BE

Volume growth and deleveraging now decoupled

In our view, Kaz Minerals has one of the more impressive growth profiles in the coming 3 years of all the copper producers, growing from ~80kt in 2015 to an estimated 290kt by 2019. However, with copper prices now lower, the deleveraging story should be pushed out closer to 2019. Just one year back volume growth and deleveraging were forecast to occur simultaneously.

Bozshakol and Aktogay projects both progressing well

The Bozshakol and Aktogay oxide projects are both complete, with just moderate spend left on Bozshakol. Aktogay oxides should be running at full production in H1 2016. We expect to see Bozshakol hit commercial production levels in Q3 2016, with 4Q 2016 the first full quarter of commercial production. Aktogay sulphides remains under construction with KAZ targeting 2017 for commissioning. Bozshakol approaching the 60-70% capacity utilisation stage will be a key stage for operational handover.

BE

East region cost control in focus for 2016

Delivering production growth from the new KAZ projects coincides with a dip in production in 2016 in the East Region mines. The Yubileyno-Snegirkhinsky mine is slated for closure in H2 2016 as it hits end of life. KAZ has guided 2016 gross unit costs to the USc200-220/lb level which is slightly down from 2015. We think that with tight cost control measures, KAZ should be able to deliver unit costs on a net basis close to 2015 levels of USc110/lb. This will be a key focus for the East Region at the half year financial stage.

Financials stretched, maturities need to be addressed

Despite good operational progress, the lower copper price over the past 6 months has added pressure to free cash generation. As a result, on our forecasts KAZ still has enough operating cash flow generation to pay for the remaining capex items, but not enough to address all debt maturities. We think up to US$700m of debt maturities for 2017 and 2018 will likely be refinanced and we expect an announcement on this topic by year end 2016.

Valuation of 120p/share, initiate with a SELL rating

We value KAZ at 120p/share on a weighted average basis, and therefore set our target price at 120p/sh. While we do not see any specific negative catalysts for the stock, we think the near term valuation is overly reliant on the copper price. With the deleveraging story shifting out further to 2019, we also see the revaluation story as less attractive near term. Bozshakol operational handover and the debt refinancing are the two announcements to watch for in 2016, but both should already be priced into the stock. We think the most positive catalyst for this stock will be a sustainable increase in the copper price to above USc230/lb.

BE

So take your pick. They'll either double or fall by 40%.

11:51 am
BE

Here's Exane.

BE

Argos reported Q1 LFL of +0.1%. Underlying LFL was +1%, when excluding the cannibalisation of new space. GM decline of -100bp was driven by adverse currency, shipping costs and mix due to strength in electrical categories. This implies LFL GP of c.-3% in the period. Unsurprisingly given the pending acquisition there is nothing in the way of outlook commentary, and hence little read-across to general retail peers.

Home Retail Group has also announced that the existing customer redress provision may need to be increased by c.£30m (via a prior period adjustment to FY16 provision of £17m) after the Group’s Financial Services division identified it had erroneously collected excess fees in relation to late payments. A more detailed review will now be undertaken. We await further detail on the nature of this revision on the call later this morning.

Q1 Headlines
LFL +0.1% (underlying LFL +1% ex the cannibalisation of new space)
GM -100bp
Implying LFL GP -3%
Online +16% (now c.50% sales)

BE

And off the conference call ..........

11:51 am
BE

With management restricted on commentary in light of the Sainsbury’s deal (which remains on track and expected to complete in 3Q) the Home Retail conference call offered limited forward looking guidance. Management were confident with momentum across the quarter, which has been supported by strong growth in electrical and furniture categories. The new financial services provision looks to cover a systemic issue over the history of the FS business (c.15yrs) and so will allay some fears over the underlying profitability of the FS business. Nonetheless, whilst clearly a company specific issue, it was triggered by a more rigorous internal review of the financial services business in anticipation of FCA authorisation – a process that other credit peers such as Next and N Brown will also follow – a reminder of the risks involved ahead of authorisation.

BE

N Brown.

BE

Flybe has reported an FY16 PBT of £5.5m (vs. a loss of £(25.4)m) compared
with our forecast of a profit of £3m, thus achieving an important milestone in
the company's transformation. This is adjusted for £2.8m of non-cash revaluation
losses on USD loans. Trading conditions in the sector were challenging during H2
and, in our opinion, the results demonstrate improved management controls and
greater resilience, with a strengthened balance sheet and progress in key KPIs.

11:59 am
BE

● Capacity: We believe the market will be pleased with action taken to slow FY16 and
FY17 capacity growth, now guided to be +15% and +6% respectively (with half FY16's
growth related to E195s deployed via airport partnerships). It will seek shareholder
approval to cancel leases for nine used Bombardier Q400s, while buying 10 aircraft for
c.£86m cash (adding to 3 bought in 2H16). Costs are expected to reduce by c.£4m in
FY17 and £8m in FY18 as it rebalances the fleet from leases towards ownership.
● Cost and revenue per seat: In FY16 revenue per seat for Flybe UK fell by 1.4%,
reflecting a 9.7% increase in seat capacity and tough market conditions. Costs were
tightly controlled with a decline of 2.2% per seat including fuel and 4.2% excluding fuel.
The unit fuel bill, we estimate, will fall by c.14% in FY17E, with 90% of fuel and currency
requirements hedged. We expect much of this benefit to be competed away.
● Legacy E-195s: Flybe absorbed £20m of legacy E195 costs above the line in FY16,
and has re-iterated, following the completion of "Project Blackbird", guidance that future
costs related to the E195s will be: £10m in FY17, £6m in FY18 and £4m in FY19.
● Outlook: Flybe says that the industry environment is "challenging," given the threat of
terrorist activity, industrial unrest in France (c.12% of capacity), consumer uncertainty
and "the highest level of seat capacity growth in the European short-haul market for
six years". It promises to "remain disciplined in pricing, continue to focus on unit cost
reduction, and maintain its capacity discipline through continuing fleet transactions."

BE

(@roddy1234: you argument hinges on the misconception that Scotland still has newspapers.)

BE

Market conditions continue to be tough and we believe that the revenue environment
has deteriorated in recent months. Flybe notes that it is already taking cost and capacity
actions to support growth in FY17 and the P&L will also benefit from lower E195 costs,
reduced fleet costs and a reduction in the unit fuel bill. Reflecting the tougher revenue
outlook, however, we are trimming our FY17E PBT forecast from £23m to £21.7m, with
more modest progress now expected in FY18E.

BE

And Liberum.

BE

BE

The FY results were marginally ahead of our forecasts and represented the
group's first positive EPS in five years as management resolved the last of
the group’s legacy issues. As well as cheaper fuel, there was notable
progress on non-fuel costs. Trading conditions remain tough, with
headwinds from fragile demand and faster capacity growth across the
industry. Capacity growth is being moderated and another deal to buy in
leased aircraft should see progress on reducing aircraft ownership costs.
Risks remain, but we see these as more than adequately reflected in the
current valuation. Our recommendation remains BUY with a 105p target
price.

Results headlines

PBT (normalised) £5.5m (0.9% margin, vs. £9.4m loss last year, Liberum £3.0m),
EPS (normalised) 4.4p (vs. -5.3p last year, Liberum 3.2p),
EPS (reported) 3.1p (vs. -16.5p last year, Liberum 2.0p),
Net cash £62.2m (vs. £76.7m last year, Liberum £72.1m),
Unrestricted cash £163.6m (vs. £177.9m last year, Liberum £153.3m).

BE

Skipping a lot.

BE

Minimal changes to estimates
We have made minimal changes to our headline estimates. We have adopted more conservative revenue assumptions, to reflects management’s cautious commentary on current trading and a weaker unit revenue outlook elsewhere in the industry. Forward bookings are softer, with H1 capacity only 43% sold compared with 46% this time last year, and unit revenue trends are lower YoY, although Flybe is biased towards later, higher yield bookings. However, this is offset by a better cost outlook, mainly from the reduction in aircraft ownership costs. 2018E EPS rises by 7% on a lower tax rate, since we consider it unlikely the group will go straight from a nil rate to the full statutory rate in a single year.
